item.title: Blogging with Wintersmith
item.description:
I've decided to start a blog with Github pages and Octopress last year. Now, I switch from Octopress to Wintersmith. Wintersmith is a NodeJS based static site generator. it is simple and fast.

Why did I change blog engine?

  • Ruby: just Octopress used Ruby on my machine. I'm a programmer and I written codes in Java and JavaScript, I've never used Ruby for other purpose.
  • Simplicity and Fast (Lean): Wintersmith is faster than Octopress generator and it has a simpler directory structure.
  • NodeJS: I like NodeJS, and I can change Wintersmith code as I want it.

item.title: Install Redmine 2.1.0 on Ubuntu Server 12.04 64bit
item.description:
We have been using Redmine for issue tracking and wiki since 2010. Thanks to wiki, everyone is able to access and share information. Major topics are:

  • How to create a new developer environment?
  • Rules and conventions: continuous delivery, version number syntax, CI job configuration, coding style, creating specification, etc.
  • SCM description: how to perform a build and deployment.
  • Runtime environments' data (test, CI, production, DVCS).

We don't share constant information over email. If this information isn't in our wiki, then

We write it into the wiki, and share wiki page.

Wiki helps you to eliminate waste! Let's see the installation process! 

sudo su -

Install LAMP server

tasksel install lamp-server

Set mysql root password, you need it later! [ref. MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD]

Install infrastructure

apt-get install ruby-full libmysqlclient-dev libmagickwand-dev libapache2-mod-passenger

Note: After this operation, 306 MB of additional disk space will be used.

Install Redmine 2.1.0

# Create redmine database
# You need MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD!
mysql -u root -p
create database redmine character set utf8;
create user 'redmine'@'localhost' identified by 'REDMINEDB_PASSWORD';
grant all privileges on redmine.* to 'redmine'@'localhost';
exit

You need REDMINEDB_PASSWORD later! 

# Download redmine
wget http://rubyforge.org/frs/download.php/76448/redmine-2.1.0.tar.gz
tar xzvf redmine-2.1.0.tar.gz
mv redmine-2.1.0 redmine
mv redmine /var/www/redmine

Configure Redmine 2.1.0

cd /var/www/redmine
cp config/database.yml.example config/database.yml

# Settings Redmine Edit database.yml
production:
adapter:        mysql
database:       redmine
host:           localhost
username:       redmine
password:       REDMINEDB_PASSWORD

# Install Rake
apt-get install rake
apt-get install ruby-bundler

The next step will take a while (about 2 minutes): 

cd config
bundle install --without development test postgresql sqlite

You must get "Your bundle is complete! Use bundle show [gemname] to see where a bundled gem is installed." 

rake generate_secret_token

# Initialize Redmine
RAILS_ENV=production rake db:migrate
RAILS_ENV=production rake redmine:load_default_data

Settings Apache

# /etc/apache2/mods-available/passenger.conf
PassengerDefaultUser www-database

#Edit /etc/apache2/sites-available/default
# Overwrite Document root
DocumentRoot /var/www/redmine/public
# Add Directory element
var/www/redmine>
  RailsBaseURI /redmine


# Set permissions and restart apache2
a2enmod passenger
cd /var/www
mkdir redmine/public/plugin_assets
chown -R www-data:www-data redmine/
chmod -R 755 redmine/
chmod -R 777 redmine/public/plugin_assets
chmod -R 777 redmine/files
service apache2 restart

After all you get an ugly message: apache2: "Could not reliably determine the server's fully qualified domain name, using 127.0.1.1 for ServerName" 

# Set server's FQ name, edit /etc/apache2/httpd.conf
# Change 'localhost' to real server name
ServerName YOUR_REAL_SERVER_NAME

# restart apache
service apache2 restart

Navigate browser to redmine server address, and redmine login page will be shown.

Change default admin/admin user's password!!!

Do not forget to set Redmine host name after login: click Setting, choose General Tab and set Host name and path to YOUR_REAL_SERVER_NAME

Conclusion

All company must have a central knowledge base that easily access by team members. Use Redmine wiki to share same information to everyone and everywhere! Wiki helps you to eliminate waste!

item.title: The Road To Continuous Delivery
item.description:
I've been working at my company since 1997. I've created with my team more than 36 Java web application and 29 Oracle database. When we started at 1997, we had just an email server, a version control (CVS) server and a bug reporting system. We didn't write unit test just Java main methods, and we didn't hear about integration test. Few years later we have started writing unit tests, and more few years later integration tests. Today, we have been using several continuous integration and delivery tools: Redmine, Maven, Jenkins, DVCS, Selenium/WebDriver, JUnit, Cucumber. To be able to achieve continuous delivery, it has to start with continuous integration. Of course, we are developing our process: we have some weakness and we can find new challenges. Before you start a continuous delivery process, your company must be mature. It's all about efficiency.

Continuous delivery is able to raise your efficiency.

Before you start Continuous Delivery or Continuous Integration, check this list:

Software Configuration Management

  1. Creating a new developer environment takes about 30 minutes.
  2. Version number syntax is carved in stone (snapshots and releases).
  3. You can create 'one step build'.
  4. Your build repeatable.
  5. You have runtime environment names.
  6. Code is able to running on developer machine.
  7. You have a Wiki, and a page with description of SCM.
  8. Lead Developer is a 'software configuration master' (master and no manager).
  9. You've a bug, task, feature database.

Developer activities

  1. Developer fixes bugs before writing new code.
  2. Developer always writes a unit test to reproduce a bug before start a bug fixing.
  3. Developer can prove the issues have been fixed (unit test, integration test).
  4. Developer can reproduce a bug on the developer machine, or at least not in the production environment.
  5. Developer knows what the project goal is.
  6. Developer knows what she/he is working on today and tomorrow.
  7. Developers have guidelines: coding style, specification, etc.

Team

  1. You must have a TEAM. Not programmers, not testers, not designers, not managers.
  2. Team size between 3-8 people.
  3. Team is older than 3 months.
  4. Team is self organized.
  5. Team visualizes up-to-date their own work, schedules and impediments.
  6. Team's able to carry out specifications, codes, automatic tests and releases.
  7. Team has been continuously developing their own process.
  8. Team is independent of other teams (or individuals).
  9. One team - one mission. One mission - one team.

Plan

  1. Product has a feature list (product backlog).
  2. You have a roadmap.
  3. You are able to do less.
  4. Product has validated before it's releasing to production.
  5. All plans have been visualized for teams (Kanban, Scrum).

Conclusion

To achieve continuous delivery: it's not a revolution, it's an evolution. You need a matured company, so in first stage: check the list, and try to achieve goals, and do not forget: to be able to achieve continuous delivery, it has to start with continuous integration.

item.title: Lean Tools of Continuous Delivery
item.description:
In the past, I have seen a development team who optimized a part of the development process. They focused on write of Java code and automated some code generation. Of course, they have been failed in delivery software. Today we have Lean Software Development, so we know what it means Optimize the Whole and Focus on the Entire Value Stream.

We have been using several tools and methods at my software development team and we focus on the entire value stream. Lean mentality requires lean tools and conscious choice!

Discussions and planning

Tools: Scrum, Whiteboard, Sketchbook, UML notation, Wiki, Email, Chat

We've been collecting continuously all requirements, because they are constantly changing. Your best friends are sketchbook and whiteboard. I'm drawing diagrams, screens, data blocks with connections, etc. Iâ€™ve always been a big fan of visualization. After all, I've publishing results: wiki, email, product backlog, etc. Do not forget to eliminate waste! Throws out heavyweight and unnecessary tools.

Continuous delivery

Tools: NetBeans, DVCS, Apache Maven, JUnit, Spring, Automated Integration Test, Automated Acceptance Test, User Acceptance Test, WebDriver, Cucumber, jMeter, Code review, Logging, Redmine

Please, do not optimize just one part of development process! Optimize the whole process from start to finish! Continuous delivery helps your team to deliver fast and maintain a good quality. How we do it: we start with Sprint planning and determine the most important tasks. Do not waste your time and money! Determine the most important tasks! If necessary, programmer and product owner create more detailed specification. Do not create unnecessary documentation! The created specification often just one page! We have been using sketchbook, whiteboard and UML drawing program. After all, we publish it.

We know, why we have been using a particular tool, this is a conscious choice.

Some examples:

  1. We do not use Eclipse editor, because NetBeans is simpler. We can start Maven project with it faster and cleaner. Tool version update is bug free. Code does not depend on it.
  2. We do not use Ant, but Maven. Maven has dependecy managment, life cycle, and is capable to release software from CLI.
  3. We use DVCS: Mercurial and Git. We can commit offline, and merge branch between developer. It is tracking changesets, not files.
  4. We have been writing unit test. This is a standard solution for testing our daily work: all unit test runs from NetBeans after every code compile, so we are always testing all changes!
  5. We use Spring Framework, because "Write Once - Run Anywhere" is working. Spring upgrade on any project are seamless. It doesn't accumulate technical debt. It is free and costless!

Jenkins CI server start testing Integration Tests and Automated Acceptance Test after code have been commited to DVCS. Cucumber is the best tool for AAT (Automated Acceptance Test). I've tested several other BDD tools (Spock, jBehave, etc.) before we start using Cucumber. Cucumber feature text is written in a business-readable domain-specific language and serves as documentation, automated tests and development-aid - all rolled into one format! Read more: The Cucumber Book: Behaviour-Driven Development for Testers and Developers - sample codes has been written in ruby, but useful to Java developers too.

Do not waste your time to try testing all feature with AAT!

Most important features has been tested with AAT, but not all. We do manual test before we release a new version (UAT), focused on new features (product backlog items). At the end of the Sprint, we show features at Sprint Review Meeting.

Conclusion

Choose your tools for Continuous Delivery and do not forget: Optimize the Whole and Focus on the Entire Value Stream

item.title: When the customer is the biggest risk
item.description:
When I start a development project with my team, I get at least two constraints: deadline and fixed budget. In my experience, deadline is near and budget is low.

So, there is no time to waste!

Using lean approach is the best way to the success. What does it mean to be lean? Check out my lean presentation

Sometimes I get more constraints from my customer, e.g: unfamiliar technology, customer's own framework, developing with non-teammate, obsolate code, etc. This looks like innocent, but it is a real threat to deadline and budget. I call them to known constraints. In addition, sometimes there are latent constraints on customer side:

  • low workplace culture
  • client is not committed
  • no customer experiences in software development
  • unreal budget

These latent constraints are very important! My experience that, any of these will lead to failure. In that case, the customer is the biggest risk.

Conclusion

Before you contract to a project consider the following viewpoints:

  1. Project has a reasonable deadline.
  2. The known constraints are acceptable and you can meet these demands.
  3. There isn't any latent constraint.

If you can say yes to all viewpoints, then start the project.
